patient_information: A 14-year-old girl from the Solomon Islands.
chief_complaint: Painless, non-healing large ulcer of her left leg.
history_of_present_illness: The ulcer began 1 month earlier and was described as painless and large.
exposure_and_epidemiology: Patient resides in the Solomon Islands, a region in the West Pacific where yaws is highly endemic and a common problem.
physical_exam: On examination, there was a large lesion (approximately 3 cm diameter) on the left lower leg covered by a layer of crust. A smaller, similar lesion was noted lower down the leg. There was no regional lymphadenopathy or evidence of any other skin or bone lesions.
labs_and_diagnostics: Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test was positive at a titre of 1:64 (Normal â€“ Negative). RPR test repeated 12 months later was positive at a titre of 1:8.
differential_diagnosis: Haemophilus ducreyi infection, pyoderma, tropical ulcer, cutaneous diphtheria, and Aeromonas hydrophila infection.
management_and_clinical_course: The patient was treated with a single intramuscular (IM) dose of benzathine benzylpenicillin. The skin lesion resolved over the next 10 days. The patient was seen again at the hospital 12 months later with a similar ulcer on the right leg. A greater than four-fold fall in the RPR titre (from 1:64 to 1:8) was considered a cure for the initial treatment. The new leg ulcer was interpreted to be of a different aetiology.
